note.note-paragraph: In this subclass non-limiting references (in the sense of paragraph 39 of the Guide to the IPC) may still be displayed in the scheme.

CPC-specific-text.text: for transmitting mechanical rotation

reference.text: fluid couplings F16D31/00 - F16D39/00; couplings or joints specially adapted for deep-drilling rods or sucker rods E21B; for transmitting motion through a wall without relatively-moving surfaces F16J15/50

non-disconnectable, e.g. involving gluing, welding or the like
by clamping together two faces perpendicular to the axis of rotation, e.g. with bolted flanges
with radial clamping due to axial loading of at least one pair of conical surfaces
for attachment of a member on a shaft or on a shaft-end

reference.text: attachment of marine propellers on shafts B63H23/34

CPC-specific-text.text: characterised by adaptors where hub bores being larger than the shaft

title-part.text: involving gluing, welding or the like

due to the elasticity of the ring or sleeve
due to axial loading of the ring or sleeve, e.g. Belleville washers
with radial clamping due to a radial screw
with radial clamping between the mating surfaces of the hub and shaft
due to the elasticity of the hub (including shrink fits)
due to tangential loading of the hub, e.g. a split hub
due to other loading elements in the hub or shaft
with axial keys and no other radial clamping
the key being axially tapered and tightening when loaded axially
the key having two axially tapered interengaging parts
with other than axial keys, e.g. diametral pins, cotter pins and no other radial clamping

CPC-specific-text.text: the clamped shaft being hollow
using a hydraulic fluid to clamp or disconnect, not provided for in F16D1/091

title-part.text: and comprising a chamber including a tapered piston moved axially by fluid pressure to effect clamping
the pair of conical mating surfaces being provided on the coupled hub and shaft
using one or more elastic segmented conical rings forming at least one of the conical surfaces, the rings being expanded or contracted to effect clamping
using one or more pairs of elastic or segmented rings with mutually mating conical surfaces, one of the mating rings being contracted and the other being expanded

title-part.text: with clamping effected by ring contraction only

reference.text: for connecting two abutting shafts F16D1/02

CPC-specific-text.text: the clamping is effected by hub contraction, i.e. a compression of the hub instead of the ring

title-part.text: the ring or rings being located between the shaft and the hub
with clamping effected by ring expansion only, e.g. with an expanded ring located between hub and shaft
Quick-acting couplings in which the parts are connected by simply bringing them together axially

the torque is transmitted via polygon shaped connections
the torque is transmitted via splined connections

title-part.text: having retaining means rotating with the coupling and acting only by friction

the interengaging parts comprising torque-transmitting surfaces, e.g. bayonet joints
the interengaging parts including a continuous or interrupted circumferential groove in the surface of one of the coupling parts

title-part.text: allowing adjustment of the parts about the axis
Yielding couplings, i.e. with means permitting movement between the connected parts during the drive

reference.text: couplings disconnectable simply by axial movement F16D1/10; slip couplings F16D7/00

title-part.text: one coupling part entering a sleeve of the other coupling part and connected thereto by sliding or rolling members

note.note-paragraph: "coupling parts" means the driving member and the driven member of the coupling to be mounted on and rotate as a unit with the shafts or their equivalents between which the coupling is placed. An intermediate member interconnecting these parts is regarded as such an equivalent.

title-part.text: one coupling part having radially projecting pins, e.g. tripod joints

CPC-specific-text.text: with linear rolling bearings between raceway and trunnion mounted shoes
with trunnion rings, i.e. with tripod joints having rollers supported by a ring on the trunnion

title-part.text: the pins extending radially outwardly from the coupling part

CPC-specific-text.text: having two pins
having three pins, i.e. true tripod joints
having four or more pins, e.g. with compensation for relative pin movement

title-part.text: the pins extending radially inwardly from the coupling part
the rolling members being balls, rollers, or the like, guided in grooves or sockets in both coupling parts
the rolling members being located in sockets in one of the coupling parts
the rolling members being guided in grooves in both coupling parts

Accelerator pedal position threshold, e.g. switch

Using the moment of inertia of a component as input for the control
Detection of an elapsed period of time
Temperature detection of any component of the control system

Accurate determination of the clutch positions, e.g. treating the signal from the position sensor, or by using two position sensors for determination
Filling the actuator cylinder with fluid
Shifting operation, i.e. volume compensation of the master cylinder due to wear, temperature changes or leaks in the cylinder
Calibration or recalibration of the actuator
Transition between manual and automatic control of the clutch
Activation of the creep control operation
Manual switch actuated by the user
Control of clutch to control engine
Adaptations of the clutch characteristics, e.g. curve clutch capacity torque - clutch actuator displacement
Cleaning of clutches, e.g. controlling the engine or the clutch to provoke vibrations eliminating particles from the clutch friction surfaces
Calibration or recalibration of the clutch touch-point
Estimation of the displacement of the clutch touch-point due to the modification of relevant parameters, e.g. temperature, wear
Control of secondary clutch in the driveline, i.e. not including clutches in automatic transmission, e.g. in the vicinity of rear axle or on parallel drive shaft
Filling level of an accumulator providing fluid for the engagement of the clutch
Control of engine accessories, e.g. air conditioning, pumps, auxiliary drive
Control of engine at idle, i.e. controlling engine idle conditions, e.g. idling speed
Preventing engine over-speed, e.g. by actuation of the main clutch
Facilitating engagement of a dog clutches, e.g. preventing of gear butting
Facilitating disengagement of a dog clutch, e.g. by applying a pretension on the disengaging elements
Shaft dither, i.e. applying a pulsating torque to a (transmission) shaft to create a buzz or dither, e.g. to prevent tooth butting or gear locking
Shaft speed synchronising, e.g. using engine, clutch outside transmission
Control of the main clutch to prevent or release a tooth-to-tooth condition in the transmission
Gearing shifting without the interruption of drive
Neutral control, i.e. preventing creep or drag torque being transmitted in a transmission with a torque converter when the vehicle is stationary
Optimising drive-train operating point, e.g. selecting gear ratio giving maximum fuel economy, best performance
Simulate the characteristics of a torque converter
Prevention or regulation of vehicle's wheel slip
Control during a braking operation, e.g. during ABS control
Control during a stability control operation [ESP]
Parking, i.e. control of drive units during parking
Stop-and-go, i.e. repeated stopping and starting, e.g. in traffic jams
Detecting abnormal operation, e.g. unwanted slip or excessive temperature
Manufacture, testing, calibrating, i.e. test or calibration of components during or soon after assembly, e.g. at the end of the production line
Driver error, i.e. preventing effects of unintended or incorrect driver inputs
Details about the implementation of the control system
Output parameters from the control unit
Quick displacement to clutch touch point
for regulating the amount of fluid flow
On/off switching of the cooling fluid flow
Modifying control system parameters, e.g. gains, constants, look-up tables
Analysing potential states of the machine and developing control strategies at each state
by provoking vibrations of a vehicle part
PWM, width modulation, frequency or amplitude modulation
